@bethematch_nybc Uzo recalls her donation experience:  Excerpt see full story on our Facebook page (link in Bio) “Someone asked me right after my donation whether I would go through the process again - I said then and I continue to feel the same, that whatever inconveniences, discomfort, one night of hospital stay, did not compare with the opportunity to  help someone facing a life threatening health crisis. I would do it again and again and hope and pray that if the circumstance were reversed, someone would do the same for me.
.
We asked Uzo the following questions: [What encouraged you to join the registry?] “I was a sophomore in college and attended the Black Family Reunion on the National Mall in Washington D.C. and spoke to someone about the fact that matches are more likely to occur within an ethnic group,  my family had lived with sickle cell through my uncle's experiences and the thought that I could do something as simple as donate blood or marrow to make a difference impacted me - I paused and signed up - that was about 25 years ago.”
.
[How do you think we can disrupt the disparity?] “I think we have to continue to tell real life stories - particularly donor stories that will combat certain myths, misstatements and misrepresentations, are important.”
.
.

tweet:
We are so thankful today and everyday for our veterans! We'd like to celebrate Veteran's Day by sharing Chris' story with you.
.
Chris is a medically retired US Marine, heart transplant recipient, stroke survivor, and now a motivational speaker.  While in the @Marines, Chris went into heart failure and suffered 3 strokes.  He had 2 open heart surgeries, the first to put in a heart pump, an LVAD, to keep him alive while he waited for a heart transplant, and the second on April 9, 2013 when he received his new heart.  Chris is now pursuing a career in Motivational Speaking and helping others in a similar health situation, both civilian and Military. .
Thank you to Chris, and all of our veterans, for your service. #VeteransDay #nybloodcenter

Temporary blood shortages are not uncommon during summer and winter holidays each year, but the COVID-19 pandemic has created a chronic shortage across the country that shows no sign of improving. This reality is particularly dangerous given the looming uncertainty surrounding the pandemic’s trajectory over the course of this winter.
.
New York’s healthcare system requires 1,500 donations each day to treat patients ranging from trauma victims to newborn babies and their mothers to cancer patients. Prior to the pandemic, donors could stop by community blood drives at convenient locations, but nearly all high schools, colleges, offices and other community groups have had to cancel their blood drives due to COVID-19. Blood donors can now make appointments to visit donor centers, but donations are at just 65% of pre-pandemic levels - well below what is needed by hospitals and patients in our area. name: New York Blood Center
tweet:
Christian suffers from Sickle Cell and requires blood transfusions every 3 weeks to stay alive. September is #SickleCellAwarenessMonth. More than 90,000 people in the U.S., mostly African-American, suffer from this blood disorder and more than 1,000 babies are born every year with this disease. Sickle Cell patients are usually diagnosed with the disease in their early childhood. Most require frequent blood transfusions to avoid the painful symptoms, anemia and stroke. Patients with sickle cell disease can develop antibodies that cause a reaction to blood transfusions. To reduce the risk of developing more antibodies with negative outcomes, patients need to be more closely matched with special blood donors, but there aren’t many.  Only 1.7% of donations are able to be used for sickle cell patients. Become a blood donor today and help patients fighting #SickleCell! #nybloodcenter

name: New York Blood Center
tweet:
Meet Kyle! In February 2017, at 15 months old, was diagnosed with a very rare and potentially fatal disease called Severe Aplastic Anemia. This disease attacks the bone marrow and causes the body’s blood values to deplete and eventually become non-existent. Kyle is one of the youngest patients to ever be diagnosed and treated for this disease. It has been a long and arduous road however with a multitude of blood and platelet transfusions, chemo therapy, numerous surgical procedures, a bone marrow transplant and more medications than we can mention, Kyle is now in a good place in his treatment. Despite this fact, this disease makes it that he will forever be at risk of needing transfusions in the future. A major part of Kyle’s treatment was an abundance of blood and platelet transfusions that would not have been possible without dedicated donors! Thank you for giving to help kids like Kyle! #nybloodcenter

Maybe you have heard of double red cell donations, or maybe you've heard it called an automated red cell donation. Either way, it's doubling up on the giving! With an automated red cell donation, you can donate two units with each visit! When giving a whole blood donation, the collection needs to be sent to the lab to separate the blood components, and then the red cells need to be filtered. With automated red cell donation, the red cells are separated and filtered immediately, making them readily available, after routine testing, for the patients who desperately need them. This type of donation can be given every 112 days. name: New York Blood Center
tweet:
September is #SickleCellAwareness month. This disease affects millions worldwide, mainly people of African descent, but also people of Hispanic, South Asian, and Middle Eastern ancestry. It is caused by a single genetic mutation that affects the shape of the oxygen carrying red blood cells, making it difficult for the red blood cells to get through small blood vessels, clogging the blood flow, and cutting off oxygen delivery to the organs. Sickle red blood cells die early, causing shortage of red cells and anemia with some cells disintegrating in the circulation, releasing toxic forms of hemoglobin that can cause tissue injury. The shortage of oxygen delivery to the organs and chronic tissue injury can lead to serious complications, including stroke and irreversible organ damage. Patients with sickle cell disease can develop antibodies that cause a reaction to blood transfusions. To reduce the risk of developing more antibodies with negative outcomes, patients need to be more closely matched with special blood donors, but there aren’t many.  Only 1.7% of donations are able to be used for sickle cell patients. Become a blood donor today and help patients fighting Sickle Cell! #nybloodcenter

tweet:
Brothers, King and Mesiah Singh, were both born with a rare blood disease known as G6PD.  This disease causes red blood cells to break down in response to certain medications, infections, or other stressors.  Unfortunately, there is no cure for this rare disease and the only life-saving treatment is a blood transfusion; the only way to keep the boys alive. Additionally, King, at the age of 2, was also diagnosed with high-risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia (blood cancer). During his 3 ½ years of chemotherapy treatment, numerous platelet and red blood cell transfusions helped save his life and because of this King is cancer free. Join us to donate in honor of these brave, rare disease warriors today at nybc.org/kingmesiah

It takes 6 to 10 blood donors to obtain the same amount of platelets we can get from a 1 platelet-only donation. Platelets help cancer patients, burn victims, and many more. name: New York Blood Center
tweet:
Meet Ariel - blood recipient, and blood donation advocate. "On March 30, 2012, as I was dropping my daughter off at school, I walked around to the trunk of my car and all of a sudden, a taxi recklessly ran into me from behind. Instead of another day at the office, I was in an ambulance. Instead of listening to the morning traffic report, I was strapped to a stretcher being transferred to a trauma center. 
.
From that point on, as word spread about the accident, everyone offered to help in any way imaginable. People have a wonderful desire to want to assist those in need. I was being well taken care of by medical personnel, but what could the rest of us do? The answer soon came to all of us: Give blood. 
.
To date, I have had 11 operations and received over 70 units of blood. The human body can only hold about 14 pints. That means that somewhere out there 70 people took the time to sit in a donor’s chair and gave a unit of blood. I’ll never know or be able to thank these 70 people who saved my life. But the least I can do is lend my name to the efforts of those collecting blood donations to replenish and increase our national supply. I want to inspire at least 70 friends, relatives, and members of the broader community to contribute blood. 
.
Then I’ll know that I will have “paid forward” to others who may one day need blood. Not everyone can give for a variety of reasons, medical and other, but the gift of everyone who does give means so much. Those who can’t donate can support, volunteer and recruit. You WILL save a life, just as someone’s blood donation helped save mine." #nybloodcenter
.
.
.

We are so moved by this random act of kindness, and paying it forward from the students of Southside High School. We are so proud to be part of this community, and we are honored to be part of remembering Anthony.
.
"Today, we are taking the time to honor a young man from Southside High School, in my hometown. Anthony Petrocelli should be graduating this year, sadly however, he lost his battle with cancer last summer.
.
This year has already been so unique for the graduating class of 2020. Considering everything that has happened since the spring, many of his fellow classmates, also Seniors, decided to take this time to honor Anthony's life. During a time when the class would be preparing for graduation, or Senior trips, they have chosen to work on this Honor Movement for their friend.
.
Our first stop was to the Blood Center. We gifted each phlebotomist with a $15 gift card to Panera Bread, a BE THE GOOD sign, and a Challenge coin. This is a very special place for many reasons. Clearly they save lives daily. They work hard to ensure great healthcare is given, but this is also where Anthony would visit to give and receive treatment.
.
Shortly after he passed, at the beginning of their Senior year, his friends held a blood drive in his honor. Anthony was very passionate about giving and being a donor.
.
Anthony is greatly missed and we are very happy to be able to share his memories with you, and his spirit."

name: New York Blood Center
tweet:
“Whether he is donating or raising awareness, Mainali's goal has always been clear. He wants to save lives by giving something of himself.” Congrats to dedicated donor Arjun Mainali on achieving 22 donations during 2020, and for receiving the New York Blood Center Presidents Award! Throughout his life, Arjun, who is from Nepal, has donated on 6 continents in 17 countries; from Ireland to Haiti, then on to Rwanda, all at his own expense. In 2020, he made 19 donations with us!
.
Arjun's children have his blood running through their veins, but he also considers the recipients of his donations family as well, and he is proud. "I have a family around the world," said Mainali, who immigrated to the U.S. in 2000. Of his trips abroad to make donations, he recalled one time he traveling to the United Kingdom for a blood donation and then flew back within a day!
.
This year, while in the middle of making a platelet donation, he received a special call, and the timing could not have been more perfect. In his own words, here's what happened:
“Around 12 o’ clock on November 24, 2020, I was donating two units of platelets to New York Blood Center. At 1:07, the staff at the center called me. "A 30-years-old patient needs platelets. Your platelet’s HLA matches hers. Can you donate either today or tomorrow?” I told her that I was donating blood in Melville Blood Donor Center through the nurse who was taking out my platelets. At that time, Trima Accel Platelets Pheresis Machine showed the required time as 118 minutes. What a coincidence! All the nurses were amazed. My platelets instantly came in handy to save the patient. I felt glad."
.
Thank you so much Arjun, for your continued dedication to helping those in need all around the world, and right here in our own community as well!
.
.

Meet AJ, a miracle baby who needs our help New York!  After trying for so long to conceive, his parents were finally blessed with their beautiful baby boy earlier this year. AJ defied the odds and stole their hearts with his smiles, giggles, and endless perfection. But at just 9-months-old, things suddenly took a turn for the worst.
.
AJ began rejecting his food and bottles – and what little he did eat had a hard time staying down. Typically, a bustling ball of energy, AJ also seemed especially fatigued. Concerned, his parents began trying to problem-solve with his pediatrician.
.
In early October, with his condition failing to improve, and on their pediatrician’s advice, his parents took him to the emergency room. The rest of the day blurred by with flashing lights, numerous tests, a rotation of nurses, and mounting anxiety. Soon, AJ was diagnosed with a rare form of myeloid leukemia and T-cell lymphoma.
.
In order to be cured, AJ needs a blood stem cell donation from an unrelated donor. However, he doesn’t currently have any matches on the Be The Match Registry®. AJ’s parents are now searching for another miracle – someone to save his life.
DNA also plays an important role in the matching process, since patients are mostly likely to match with donors who share their ethnic background. AJ is of Filipino descent, which means his donor is more likely to come from this community. Unfortunately, Filipinos are significantly underrepresented on the registry.
.

⁉ #IlPresidenteRisponde #Avis
Risposta:
I #test #sierologici sono test diagnostici che si eseguono normalmente in clinica e servono per misurare soprattutto all’interno del siero e del plasma dei pazienti o dei soggetti sani le quantità di proteine presenti.
Queste proteine sono di diversa natura (come l’albumina che è una proteina usata abitualmente dall’organismo per la sua sopravvivenza) oppure si sviluppano durante processi infiammatori (per esempio la proteina C reattiva) oppure sono proteine abbondantemente presenti nel siero, come gli anticorpi e le immunoglobuline, che sono risposte immunitarie del nostro organismo a insulti di tipo infettivo, che danno la cosiddetta “memoria immunologica” (che può essere recente o che può durare per tutta la vita) -
